results.title: Big brawl of '36
results.brief_description:
A personal and humorous account of a game between Benambra and Swifts Creek in 1936, where tempers flared and even the umpire was disqualified in the aftermath.

Thank you to Swifts Creek Football Club, ABC Gippsland (Photography Gerard Callinan) and Gordon Bock.

TRANSCRIPT

My first game in 1936 we had to go to Benambra and apparently there were very, very hard feelings between Swifts Creek and Benambra. It came over from the Grand Final the year before, which Swifts Creek won. I came here in September ’35 and they’re still celebrating their win against Benambra and apparently Benambra weren’t happy about it. So, I thought next year, first game next year was out at Benambra and it was sort of an evening up job…

Got to nearly half time an’ developed into a general brawl. I was playing on the wing and I was lucky, my opponent he wasn’t too keen to go in and neither was I, so we looked on. And I thought “By Jesus, they play fair dinkum over ‘ere”. I think there were over ten blokes rubbed out and I think the umpire was alto rubbed out and scrubbed. He happened to be a local bloke here, an’ he’s a great mate of mine but I’d say is the worst umpire I ever seen in my life. He completely lost control of the game altogether. One bloke got rubbed out for life, he was reported for kicking the umpire, somebody kicked the umpire and quite candidly I think he needed kicking meself. And it was in the days of the Depression and there’s a lot of Sustenance workers, Susso’s we used to call ‘em, working on the roads and that’s probably why the standard of football was very good because we had a lot of people came out into the country, poor fellows you know, that were willing to work for their keep an’ their tucker and that sort of thing…an’ they had a big Sustenance worker camp out doing up the Corryong Road and this fellow that got rubbed out for life he was one of them.

But nowadays Benambra an’ the Creek are quite good mates, we get on very well I think, don’t we?

Swifts Creek had a little Rover and apparently he had an enemy at Benambra, he was also a Rover and he said, all of a sudden there’s this bloke he’s down, see, an’ he said I was just gunna race in and slip the boot in and some dirty bugger hit me from behind.

group_siblings.title: Looking for a game at Lake Tyers

results.title: Backbone of the club
results.brief_description:
They’re tireless workers for the cause. The Ladies’ Committee of the Shepparton Football Club serve up endless meals on a Thursday night and cater for weddings, parties, anything in order to keep their club afloat.

Thank you to Val Dominelli, Jan Enders, Roe Harrap, and Tom Greenaway.

TRANSCRIPT

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: I joined the ladies’ committee in 1956. I was a very quiet, shy, retiring girl, and my mum brought me along to join the ladies’ committee. We both joined at the same time. And I’ve been on the committee ever since.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

Backbone of the club

STORY CREDITS
Detail
Backbone of the Club
A film by Malcolm McKinnon
Football Stories from Country Victoria, An initiative of the Victorian Country Football League and the State Library of Victoria, 2007

Contributors

Terms of use
Contact the copyright holder or content contributor(s) listed at the bottom of the story home page.

Malcolm McKinnon, 2006.

They’re tireless workers for the cause. The Ladies’ Committee of the Shepparton Football Club serve up endless meals on a Thursday night and cater for weddings, parties, anything in order to keep their club afloat.

Thank you to Val Dominelli, Jan Enders, Roe Harrap, and Tom Greenaway.

Further Information
TRANSCRIPT

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: I joined the ladies’ committee in 1956. I was a very quiet, shy, retiring girl, and my mum brought me along to join the ladies’ committee. We both joined at the same time. And I’ve been on the committee ever since.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

The ladies’ committee is the main fundraiser for the club. We do a lot of catering. Over the years, we’ve done lots of weddings, and we’ll do anything to raise money, any sort of function that we can run in this room.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

We raise about $26,000 to $28,000, depending on what functions we have through the years. And the club, you know, they just couldn’t survive without that money.

We have tea every Thursday night in the football season. We usually start the pre-season. All the players come in. Committees, supporters— anybody’s welcome. And home games, we just run the canteens. And I start early, about quarter past 7:00, every Saturday, and the others come in about 8:00.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

Backbone of the club

STORY CREDITS
Detail
Backbone of the Club
A film by Malcolm McKinnon
Football Stories from Country Victoria, An initiative of the Victorian Country Football League and the State Library of Victoria, 2007

Contributors

Terms of use

Malcolm McKinnon, 2006.

They’re tireless workers for the cause. The Ladies’ Committee of the Shepparton Football Club serve up endless meals on a Thursday night and cater for weddings, parties, anything in order to keep their club afloat.

Thank you to Val Dominelli, Jan Enders, Roe Harrap, and Tom Greenaway.

Further Information
TRANSCRIPT

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: I joined the ladies’ committee in 1956. I was a very quiet, shy, retiring girl, and my mum brought me along to join the ladies’ committee. We both joined at the same time. And I’ve been on the committee ever since.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

The ladies’ committee is the main fundraiser for the club. We do a lot of catering. Over the years, we’ve done lots of weddings, and we’ll do anything to raise money, any sort of function that we can run in this room.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

We raise about $26,000 to $28,000, depending on what functions we have through the years. And the club, you know, they just couldn’t survive without that money.

We have tea every Thursday night in the football season. We usually start the pre-season. All the players come in. Committees, supporters— anybody’s welcome. And home games, we just run the canteens. And I start early, about quarter past 7:00, every Saturday, and the others come in about 8:00.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

JAN ENDERS: I’ve had three sons play over the years. And I get on well with the ladies, so I’ll turn up and help. We never miss the footy. We like away games because we can watch. Home games, I have most to do with the lolly stall and keeping the drinks in the fridge and backing up in the kitchen. We sometimes see the last quarter. Don’t see much else.

[SEWING MACHINE WHIRRING]

I do all the sewing, and if there’s any repairs, I take them home, bring them back Saturday morning. Our thirds and reserves won last year, and we’ve always let them have their jumpers. So you order your jumpers very early and you don’t know what players you’re going to have in sizes. So I’ve probably sewed on 100 numbers prior to the start of the season.

ROE HARRAP: I started off going with a guy who played here, ended up marrying him, and now my children are playing here. So yeah, it really is a family affair.

[LAUGHTER]

Women are at backbone s of the football club here. I believe that women play a huge role in country football. And particularly here, if he didn’t have the women behind the club, they wouldn’t be where they are now.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: Oh, I love the club, and I love all the people. We’re all good friends. Actually, last week we were very short in the seconds. I got named as an emergency on the bench.

[LAUGHTER]

But this way, I think I got more players back. I said, well, just get me some boots and I’ll be right.

group_siblings.title: Looking for a game at Lake Tyers

results.title: Why?
results.creator_credit: Tehree Gordon and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Tehree says she is an ordinary Australian, though she was a recipient of the Senior Australian of the Year Award in 2004. In this story, Tehree talks about her passion for wildlife from an early age leading to her founding Jirrahlinga Koala and Wildlife Sanctuary with her partner Hamish. The sanctuary has provided work opportunities and enrichment to people living with disabilities and the elderly.

results.title: Kodak Movie Light and two bulbs
results.brief_description: “Kodak Movie light 220 x 140V 1000W V/XS/200 label on reverse says: do not earth. double insulation. On and Off switch: 250V A.C. only. ELMACO Australian plug: Peaston, 250V 7.5A V/A50/1 Two - Philips Photolita bulbs in their original boxes. Photolita* trademark PF218E 43 Photolita - NM 250V 500W C8 Made in Holland With one instruction pamphlet which has guide numbers of the exposure times.”

results.title: Eumig Wien Type P8 Electrical Projector in box
results.brief_description:
Boxed Projector Eumig Wien Type P8 electrical projector Housed in Vinyl bound box. Green felt covered board/lid for inside box. This board has a leather tab which helps to lift the board up. The top metal handle on the projector can be clicked in to stay up, or it can be pushed down. The feet at the front are adjustable and allow for a tilting adjustment. Lens: Coated Eupro F1.6 25mm lens The machine must be opened to erect the spool arms. Brown power cord with a Eumig logo. Australian power plug (Ring grip, 10 AMP, 250 V, Made in Australia) English instruction manual enclosed. Eumig metal spool housed in original cardboard box. Made in Austria.

Reel capacity: 120m / 400ft diameter: 175mm diameter x 13mm depth Kelvin clear plastic spool. Made in Australia.

Reel capacity: 120m / 400ft diameter: 177mm diameter x 14mm depth yellow piece of card ribbon inside.

2 identical Philips projection lamps in their original boxes with double sided instructions. The lamp inside the box is packaged between two pieces of corrugated cardboard. 7238N / 05 12V 100W B15S A8 Made in Germany

Broken brush made from real hair. Made in Japan. (used for cleaning?)

The top metal handle on the projector can be clicked in to stay up, or it can be pushed down. The feet at the front are adjustable and allow for a tilting adjustment. Lens: Coated Eupro F1.6 25mm lens The machine must be opened to erect the spool arms. Brown power cord with a Eumig logo. Australian power plug (Ring grip, 10 AMP, 250 V, Made in Australia) English instruction manual enclosed. Eumig metal spool housed in original cardboard box. Made in Austria.

Reel capacity: 120m / 400ft diameter: 175mm diameter x 13mm depth Kelvin clear plastic spool. Made in Australia.

Reel capacity: 120m / 400ft diameter: 177mm diameter x 14mm depth yellow piece of card ribbon inside.

2 identical Philips projection lamps in their original boxes with double sided instructions. The lamp inside the box is packaged between two pieces of corrugated cardboard. 7238N / 05 12V 100W B15S A8 Made in Germany

Broken brush made from real hair. Made in Japan. (used for cleaning?)

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 2 - Orange
results.creator_credit: Adem Jaffers, Frank Peppard and G-O-D/ G=enerator, O=perator, D=estroyer
results.brief_description:
Please note, this video may potentially trigger seizures for people with photosensitive epilepsy. Viewer discretion is advised.

Cyberthon V: Spectrum Orange was broadcast as the second of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Zen Paradox (Sapphire), Andy Taylor (Air Fiction), Andy Taylor, Mad Club (Danny Slim, Susan Clinch, Bernie Grogan & Matt the Tree), Digital Primate (Christopher Coe) and Anticraft (Al Vandermede).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 2 - Orange is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Cyberthon I: For the Mind, Body and Soul
results.brief_description:
‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ was the first guerrilla TV broadcast event of its namesake following the success of the Cyberdelia broadcast a year earlier. Conceptualised as a ‘marathon cyber’ event, ‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ saw a group of artists broadcast, remix, VJ and DJ mastered footage, experimental Amiga graphics and electronic art alongside performers and a live band at RMITV’s studio in Melbourne. Collaborator and curator to the events, Adem Jaffers said this is where the Cyberthon events really began and over the next four years they would expand in scope to feature over 300 VJ’s, DJ’s, artists, performers and collaborators. 

Visual Artists: Nuero (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Troy Innocent, Dale Nason and Elena Popa), Future Films (Jeff Jaffers), Interscreen (Kimberley Hughes), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi)

Audio Artists: Blast Off Sound System (Jason ‘Rudeboy’ Mac and Terence ‘H20’ Ho), Third Eye (Ollie Olsen), Acid Death Bed (Darren Porter and Paul Wain), Baby Lemonade Lemar (Andrea), Captain ROM

Performers: Taz (Tasilim Emiabata), Star (Raquel Webb), Lizette Broulathaki

‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: [Fred Daley Collection]
results.material_description: 8mm home movie reels (small and large). Most already digitised.
results.brief_description:
A collection of silent, 8mm home movies by steam train enthusiast Fred Daley, capturing scenes of steam trains, the Daley family, vintage cars, railway stations, and snapshots of rural and city life.

The films are mainly shot on family holidays in various locations across Victoria from the City of Melbourne to Warburton, Apollo Bay and Mornington Peninsula, to a long road trip to Cooma, New South Wales. There is also a work specially dedicated to Victoria’s most famous steam train, Puffing Billy.

Fred was a skilled filmmaker - we are presented with polished films, employing use of a tripod, nifty title sequences and astute editing. Whilst filming steam trains was his passion, made evident by the many hours of footage dedicated to them, Fred also shows the family’s love of the outdoors on summer holidays, road trips, gardens, Luna Park, a game of football at the MCG, picnics and relaxing on the beach.

The titles shown here were made from the mid-to-late 1960s but Fred’s collection spans some fifty years. Kindly donated to the ACMI Collection by Fred’s son Neville, Fred’s Films provide memories not only for his family but also for the collective memory of Victorians, steam train buffs, filmmakers, historians, or anyone who has the pleasure of watching them.

A collection of silent home movies filmed by train enthusiast Fred Daley.
Footage of:
Daley Family
Steam trains
Vintage cars
Railway stations
Family holidays
Locations across Victoria
Warburton
Echuca
Heathcote
Mornington
Tasmania
Alice Springs

results.title: Fred's Films. [Luna Park] [excerpt]
results.brief_description: Filmed in the mid 1960s by steam train enthusiast and home movie maker Fred Daley who captures a family outing to the popular sea-side amusement park in St Kilda. ‘Luna Park’ is shown in all its summertime glory with the ‘River Boats’, the ‘Dodgems’, the ‘Rotor’ (a washing spin cycle for humans!), ‘The Spinner’ and of course its famous wooden roller coasters, the ‘Big Dipper’ and the ‘Scenic Railway’. Courageous Fred even films during the ride where you catch a glimpse of Port Phillip Bay from the very top!
results.description: Filmed in the mid 1960s by steam train enthusiast and home movie maker Fred Daley who captures a family outing to the popular sea-side amusement park in St Kilda. ‘Luna Park’ is shown in all its summertime glory with the ‘River Boats’, the ‘Dodgems’, the ‘Rotor’ (a washing spin cycle for humans!), ‘The Spinner’ and of course its famous wooden roller coasters, the ‘Big Dipper’ and the ‘Scenic Railway’. Courageous Fred even films during the ride where you catch a glimpse of Port Phillip Bay from the very top!
